text:
BY RICH HAMMOND / STAFF WRITER
Published: Oct. 10, 2015 Updated: Oct. 11, 2015 9:39 a.m. Jack Jablonski plans a future in hockey. Heâs also wise enough not to plan too much else.
In Dec. 2011, Jablonski, then a 16-year-old high school sophomore from Minnesota, was paralyzed from the chest down after he took a hit from behind during a hockey game. His spinal cord was severed at the neck.

Jablonski has already had an impact on hockey. His injury raised awareness about safety in youth games and the need to eliminate dangerous, blindside hits.
His mobility now limited to a motorized wheelchair, Jablonski isnât focused on his limits. He has already spent two-plus years hosting a weekly hockey-talk radio show in Minnesota, and in January, Jablonski accepted a scholarship to attend USC and study journalism and communications.

I donât know where I want to go and what I want to do exactly, but thatâs what this time is for, and Iâm looking forward to figuring it out.â
Jablonski hopes to walk one day, and pushes for spinal-cord research. Family members and friends helped organize and run Jablonskiâs âBEL13VE Foundation,â which raises money to support survivors of spinal-cord injuries and to promote further research.
Jablonski said he is enjoying life in Southern California and, even though heâs now a Kings staffer, heâs looking forward to next weekâs visit from his favorite team, the Minnesota Wild.
âThis is the first time Iâve started hockey season (with the temperature) in the 90s,â Jablonski joked.

Dustin Brown moved up from the third line to the first line, with Anze Kopitar and Marian Gaborik. Milan Lucic dropped to the second line with Jeff Carter and Tyler Toffoli, while Tanner Pearson dropped from the second line to the third line with Nick Shore and Trevor Lewis.
